Award.AwardTitle: Plasmonic Nanotexturing of Bioabsorbable Drug-Eluting Stents

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant provides funding to design, fabricate and test a new class of polymer stents for treating cardio-vascular disease. We will investigate the texturing of these stents with arrays of nano-scale features using a novel nanomanufacturing process. The hypothesis is that nano-scale texturing, unlike texturing at micron sizes or larger scales, will prevent blood clots that would allow cardio-patients enjoy the important possibilities of extended life. In the proposed work, plasmons will be generated using a laser technique and utilized to produce nano-scale protrusions and nanoparticles on the polymeric stents with a focus on scalability issues such as size uniformity, throughput, cost and repeatability. The drug will be applied to the nanotextured stents and its effects on the drug storage, drug effectiveness and polymer degradation will be evaluated. A cardiologist in the advisory role will provide continuous input during the progress of the project so as to achieve an efficient and safe nanotextured drug eluting stent.

The results of this research will lead to the prevention of late stent blood clots. Thus, the project has potential to reduce the healthcare spending in the cardiovascular market. The proposed process could also be an enabling technology in other fields such as semiconductors, organic solar cells and nanoelectromechanical systems (NEMS). The project will also offer new knowledge of laser-induced plasmonics for nano-scale processing that represents an important area in nanomanufacturing. The proposed work will impact education through an annual organization of the symposium "Nanomanufacturing Innovations in Medical Devices" with results disseminated through booth exhibits in local and national Medical Design and Manufacturing conferences and Iowa State Fair impacting a large number of visitors. In addition, the work will contribute to K-12 STEM education at Iowa State University by developing an inquiry module, "Learn Nanotechnology" for students in grades 9-12.

Institution.Name: Iowa State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF CMMI project aims to develop new nanotexturing techniques for polymer surfaces. Of special interest are the surfaces of bioimplantable and/or biodegrable polymers that can be incorporated into human body for long-term biomedical operations. One good example is poly (l-lactic acid) (PLLA) which is frequently adopted to build bioabsorbable coronary stents. Nanoscale surface texturing of such devices can diversify their functionalities, improve their efficiency, and prolong their lifetime. For instance, the operation period of drug eluting stents can be made significantly shorter or longer through judicious use of nanopatterns on their surfaces. Nature is also replete with examples of clever use of nanoscale textures for optical, mechanical, and rheological applications, functioning as a vast source of bioinspirations.

Realization and utilization of such nanotextures on polymers, however, have been hurdled so far by two main issues. Above all, it was difficult to find effective techniques to texture polymer surfaces at the nanoscale. Carrying out the nanotexturing at the level of manufacturing for healthcare industry was even more difficult. The soft and heat-sensitive natures of most polymers were the first challenge to overcome. The second hurdle originated from our lack of understanding on how the biofluids interact with nanotextured surfaces.

Our project has made progresses in both areas. Regarding the fabrication technology, we have established two major new technique for nanotexturing of polymer surfaces. More specifically, we have demonstrated nanoscale imprinting of PLLA, for the first time, to texture its surface with nanoscale cup patterns. Through a related work, we have also established a new technique for adding nanoscale volcanic patterns on photopolymer surfaces through combined utilization of nanoscale static charge generation and electrohydrodynamic lithography (EHDL). The work was especially significant and transformative in connecting two seemingly unrelated fields of study, i.e., surface electricity and nanofabrication, as shown in Figure 1.

Our fabrication work is also significant and transformative in shedding a new light on a phenomenon which has been puzzling scientists for centuries, i.e., the triboelectricity, through a multi-faceted, cross-disciplinary approach, as shown schematically in Figure 2. There, in order to study the origin and characteristics of the static electricity generation at the nanoscale, we have utilized nanoscale fabrication, atomic force microscopy, Kelvin probe force microscopy, electrostatic force microscopy, and finite-element analysis, all in combination. The result was a physical model of the nanoscale static electricity generation process capable of predicting the shape of the nanoscale charge distributions based on the geometry of the initial setup.

Regarding the investigation of the nanotexture-biofluid interaction, we have also made a significant progress by unveiling a rather counter-intuitive phenomenon, as shown schematically in Figure 3. There, we showed that the dissolving speed of the nanotextured PLLA in liquid was actually lower, rather than higher, than that of untextured ones, despite the fact that nanotexturing almost doubled the surface area. Through theoretical and numerical modeling, we revealed that the hidden mechanism was the reduction in the surface wettability. The fluid simply could not go into the nanoscale textures, let alone dissolving them. The result clearly showed that nanotexturing can be a very effective tool for controlling the interaction between the human body and the polymeric stents implanted in it. The nanotextutes can control drug elution in the human body and have beneficial applications to health care.

Both of these achievements are highly transformative in their inherently cross-disciplinary nature. We have strived to harmonize nanoscale observations, intuitions, inter-disciplinary characterizations, and theoretical modeling that will be useful to researchers in other fields. They, along with other outcomes of the project, also provide broader impacts on society first by offering a potential solution for further promotion of bioimplantable devices and second, by stimulating interests on bioimplantables and related material studies. The efforts culminated in high impact publications in widely subscribed academic journals. Overall, the benefits of our outcomes will reach well beyond the field of nanofabrication and draw attention from the general public.

Modified by: Rana Biswas

    Jaeyoun Kim

  • A schematic diagram of our study on the nanofluidic interaction between the nanotextured PLLA surface and liquid. It shows that surface nanotexturing actually reduces the level of surface-fluid interaction, despite the increase in the surface area, by decreasing the surface wettability.
    Iowa State University
    Jaeyoun Kim
    Figure 3
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This NSF CMMI project aims to develop new nanotexturing techniques for polymer surfaces. Of special interest are the surfaces of bioimplantable and/or biodegrable polymers that can be incorporated into human body for long-term biomedical operations. One good example is poly (l-lactic acid) (PLLA) which is frequently adopted to build bioabsorbable coronary stents. Nanoscale surface texturing of such devices can diversify their functionalities, improve their efficiency, and prolong their lifetime. For instance, the operation period of drug eluting stents can be made significantly shorter or longer through judicious use of nanopatterns on their surfaces. Nature is also replete with examples of clever use of nanoscale textures for optical, mechanical, and rheological applications, functioning as a vast source of bioinspirations. Realization and utilization of such nanotextures on polymers, however, have been hurdled so far by two main issues. Carrying out the nanotexturing at the level of manufacturing for healthcare industry was even more difficult. The soft and heat-sensitive natures of most polymers were the first challenge to overcome. The second hurdle originated from our lack of understanding on how the biofluids interact with nanotextured surfaces. Our project has made progresses in both areas. Regarding the fabrication technology, we have established two major new technique for nanotexturing of polymer surfaces. The work was especially significant and transformative in connecting two seemingly unrelated fields of study, i.e., surface electricity and nanofabrication, as shown in Figure 1. Our fabrication work is also significant and transformative in shedding a new light on a phenomenon which has been puzzling scientists for centuries, i.e., the triboelectricity, through a multi-faceted, cross-disciplinary approach, as shown schematically in Figure 2. They, along with other outcomes of the project, also provide broader impacts on society first by offering a potential solution for further promotion of bioimplantable devices and second, by stimulating interests on bioimplantables and related material studies. The efforts culminated in high impact publications in widely subscribed academic journals.
